choices.text: Begin a new course of rabies vaccination; no need for rabies immune globulin (RIG)
Administer rabies immune globulin (RIG) and begin a new course of rabies vaccination
Administer booster doses of rabies vaccine; no need for rabies immune globulin (RIG)
Clean the wound thoroughly; no further treatment is needed since the patient was previously vaccinated

questions.text: A 30-year-old veterinarian presents to the clinic after being bitten by a raccoon during a wildlife rescue operation. The raccoon's rabies status is unknown, and the wound is categorized as a category III exposure (transdermal bite). The veterinarian's last rabies vaccination was five years ago. What is the most appropriate management for post-exposure prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Administer booster doses of rabies vaccine; no need for rabies immune globulin (RIG)

 

Option C:

 

In the case of a previously vaccinated individual (complete pre-exposure prophylaxis), such as this veterinarian: 

 

Category III exposure (e.g. transdermal bite, mucosal exposure to saliva) does warrant PEP, But rabies immune globulin (RIG) is NOT required in those who were previously vaccinated.
 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Even previously vaccinated individuals may require a booster dose of rabies vaccine after an exposure, depending on the time elapsed since the last vaccination.

 

Option B. Administer RIG and begin a new course of rabies vaccination: RIG is not indicated in previously vaccinated persons, and a full vaccine course is unnecessary.

 

Option D. Cleaning the wound is essential for all rabies exposures, but further treatment with rabies vaccine and possibly RIG is indicated for category III exposures, especially if the last vaccination was five years ago.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Figure: Adapted from “Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins: WHO position April 2018”

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p501, 2/e p520-521

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus

questions.text: A 25-year-old laboratory technician working in a virology research facility accidentally pricks herself with a needle while handling a culture. She was working with a virus known to cause encephalitis with a bullet-shaped morphology. Which of the following is the most likely virus she was exposed to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies virus

 

Option B:

 

The rabies virus is characterized by its bullet-shaped morphology, which is distinctive and visible on electron microscopy. This is a hallmark feature that helps differentiate it from other viruses that can cause encephalitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus can cause encephalitis but does not have a bullet-shaped morphology.

 

Option C. West Nile virus is a flavivirus transmitted by mosquitoes and does not have a bullet-shaped morphology.

 

Option D. Eastern equine encephalitis virus, while a cause of encephalitis, is an alphavirus and also lacks the bullet-shaped morphology associated with the rabies virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the unique bullet-shaped morphology of the rabies virus is important for laboratory identification and differentiating it from other encephalitis-causing viruses.

 

 

Figure: Rabies virus: A. Schematic diagram; B. Electron micrograph (arrows showing).

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p496

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fever, malaise, and altered mental status. His family reports that he was bitten by a wild animal a month ago while hiking. On examination, he has hydrophobia and aerophobia. A brain biopsy reveals eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons. Which virus is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies virus

 

Option B:

 

The presence of eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons, known as Negri bodies, is pathognomonic for rabies infection. These are found in various parts of the brain and are a diagnostic hallmark of the disease.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox and shingles, which can lead to central nervous system involvement, but it does not produce Negri bodies.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus can cause CNS infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, and forms "owl's eye" inclusions, not Negri bodies.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex virus can lead to encephalitis with Cowdry type A inclusion, which are different from Negri bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic Negri bodies in neurons is crucial in confirming rabies infection, especially when there is a history of animal bite and symptoms like hydrophobia and aerophobia.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan 9/e p534

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her friends after exhibiting aggressive behavior and confusion. She has a fever and is combative, making the examination difficult. Her friends mention she was bitten by a stray dog while camping about 4 weeks ago. On examination, she has hydrophobia and hypersalivation. A brain biopsy of the dog that bit her shows intracytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following pathologies is most likely observed in the dog's brain biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negri bodies

 

Option B:

 

Negri bodies are pathognomonic for rabies and are intracytoplasmic inclusions typically found within neurons in the brain. They are a critical diagnostic clue when examining brain tissues of both infected humans and animals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lewy bodies are associated with Parkinson’s disease and dementia with Lewy bodies, not rabies.

 

Option C. Babesia parasites would not be seen in the brain and are associated with tick-borne illnesses.

 

Option D. Tau protein aggregates are a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease, not rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The behavioural changes post-animal bite and identifying Negri bodies upon examination of brain tissue are critical for diagnosing rabies.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan 9/e p534

choices.text: Electron microscopy of the corneal scrapings
Fluorescent antibody test on the corneal scrapings
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of saliva for rabies virus
Complement fixation test of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male farmer presents with a history of hydrophobia and agitation. He reports being bitten by a bat while exploring a cave two weeks prior. He has not sought medical attention until now due to his remote location. Examination reveals anxiety and spasms of swallowing muscles when presented with water. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm rabies in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluorescent antibody test on the corneal scrapings

 

Option B:

 

The fluorescent antibody test (direct fluorescent antibody test) performed on corneal impressions is a reliable and rapid method to diagnose rabies. It can detect rabies antigen in corneal cells and has a high sensitivity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Electron microscopy can reveal virus-like particles, but it is not the standard diagnostic test for rabies.

 

Option C. PCR of saliva is also a sensitive method for rabies detection, but in the setting of hydrophobia and clinical suspicion, the fluorescent antibody test on corneal scrapings is more definitive.

 

Option D. The complement fixation test is not commonly used for rabies diagnosis and has lower sensitivity compared to the fluorescent antibody test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of rabies using the fluorescent antibody test on corneal scrapings, highlighting the need for a rapid and sensitive diagnostic method in patients presenting with classic symptoms such as hydrophobia after a potential rabies virus exposure.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p499, 2/e p520

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for rabies virus on the corneal scraping
Direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test on the corneal scraping
Histopathological examination of the corneal scraping for Negri bodies
Serology for rabies virus antibodies in blood

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with a history of severe hydrophobia and anxiety. She reports a bat bite 2 months ago but did not seek medical attention at the time. On physical examination, she is agitated, has spasms of the swallowing muscles when presented with water, and reports a tingling sensation around the wound site. A corneal scraping is obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm rabies in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test on the corneal scraping

 

Option B:

 

The DFA test is considered the gold standard for the laboratory diagnosis of rabies. It allows for the rapid detection of rabies virus antigens in tissue specimens such as corneal scrapings and is highly sensitive and specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PCR for rabies virus can also be performed on corneal scrapings and is a highly sensitive method; however, DFA is the standard practice.

 

Option C. Histopathological examination for Negri bodies is less commonly used due to the need for a brain biopsy, which is not practical in a living patient.

 

Option D. Serology can be used, but it is less direct than DFA testing and might not be positive early in the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic approach to a patient with clinical features suggestive of rabies, focusing on the use of the DFA test on corneal scrapings to detect rabies virus antigens rapidly.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p499, 2/e p520

choices.text: Negri bodies in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum
Negri bodies in the pyramidal cells of the hippocampus
Negri bodies in the neurons of the basal ganglia
Negri bodies in the neurons of the subcortical white matter

questions.text: A pathologist is reviewing brain tissue samples from a patient who died of suspected rabies encephalitis. The presence of which of the following would be least likely to support a diagnosis of rabies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Negri bodies in the neurons of the subcortical white matter

 

Option D:

 

Negri bodies are pathognomonic of rabies and are typically found in certain neurons such as those in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, pyramidal cells of the hippocampus, and neurons of the basal ganglia. They are not commonly found in the neurons of the subcortical white matter.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Negri bodies are commonly found in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum in rabies.

 

Option B. Negri bodies are also typically found in the pyramidal cells of the hippocampus in rabies.

 

Option C. The presence of Negri bodies in the neurons of the basal ganglia is consistent with rabies infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pathological findings in rabies encephalitis, specifically the typical presence of Negri bodies in the neurons of certain brain regions, and their absence in the subcortical white matter.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p498, 2/e p520, Ananthanarayan 9/e p537

questions.text: During an autopsy of a patient with a suspected viral encephalitis, a pathologist observes intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies within neurons. Which of the following types of inclusion bodies would be indicative of rabies infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negri bodies

 

Option C:

 

Negri bodies are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions typically found within the neurons of individuals infected with the rabies virus. They are considered pathognomonic for rabies.

 

Diagnosis of Rabies may be made postmortem by demonstration of Negri bodies in the brain, but they may be absent in 20% of cases:

 

  • Negri bodies are most abundant in hippocampus and cerebellum
  • Impression smears made from brain tissue are stained by Seller’s technique.
  •  Negri bodies are seen as intracytoplasmic, round/oval,purplish pink structures with characteristic basophilic inner granules

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cowdry Type A bodies are intranuclear inclusions commonly associated with herpesvirus infections.

 

 

Option B. Lewy bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkinson's disease.

 

 

Option D. Guarnieri bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions associated with vaccinia and other poxvirus infections.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p498, 2/e p520, Ananthanarayan 9/e p533, 8/e p529

questions.text: A public health official is planning an educational campaign about rabies prevention and is targeting areas with known endemic rabies. Which of the following areas in India should be excluded from the campaign due to being a recognized rabies-free zone?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lakshadweep Island

 

Option B:

 

Lakshadweep island is recognized as a rabies-free zone in India and would not be a target for a rabies prevention campaign.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Andaman and Nicobar Islands are not recognized as a rabies-free zone.

 

Option C. Goa is not recognized as a rabies-free zone.

 

Option D. West Bengal is not recognized as a rabies-free zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lakshadweep island is recognized as a rabies-free zone in India 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p501-2, 2/e p523, Park 24/e p294

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic after being bitten by his neighbor's dog. The dog is up to date on all vaccinations, appears healthy, and has no history of unusual behavior. According to standard rabies prevention guidelines, for how long should the dog be observed before it can be determined that it was not shedding the rabies virus at the time of the bite?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10 days

 

Explanation:

 

The standard observation period for a dog that has bitten someone is 10 days. If the dog remains healthy throughout this period, it is considered that it was not shedding the rabies virus at the time of the bite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The observation period for a biting dog, which is crucial in the post-exposure management of the bitten individual, is 10 days.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p502, 2/e p522 Park 23/e p276-81, 24/e p298

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after being bitten on the leg by a stray dog. The wound is superficial but bleeding. The current recommendation for the initial management of animal bites to prevent rabies infection includes immediate wound cleaning. For how long should the wound be washed with soap and water?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15 minutes



Explanation

Immediate and thorough washing of the wound for at least 15 minutes with soap and water is a critical first step in rabies prevention as it can significantly reduce the viral load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of animal bites is the washing of wound for at least 15 minutes with soap and water to reduce the risk of rabies transmission.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p500, 2/e p521-522, Park 23/e p278, 24/e p296

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is developing a new vaccine for rabies. For the vaccine to be effective and safe, it must utilize a virus that will not cause disease in humans but will still provoke an immune response. What type of virus should the company use for the production of an effective rabies vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixed virus

 

Option C:

 

The rabies vaccine is prepared from fixed viruses, which are inactivated viruses that have been treated to lose their pathogenicity but maintain immunogenicity, ensuring they cannot cause disease but can still elicit an immune response.

 

Please add image

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Attenuated live viruses are used in some vaccines but not typically for rabies due to safety concerns.

 

Option B. Phenol-inactivated viruses refer to a method of inactivation, not a type of virus used for vaccines.

 

Option D. Wild-type viruses are the natural, disease-causing form of the virus and would not be used in vaccines due to the risk of causing disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rabies vaccine is prepared from fixed viruses

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p500-501, 2/e p521-522, Ananthanarayan 9/e p535

choices.text: Class I exposure – administer tetanus vaccine only
Class II exposure – administer tetanus vaccine and consider rabies post-exposure prophylaxis.
Class III exposure – administer rabies post-exposure prophylaxis and tetanus vaccine
Not an exposure – no treatment necessary

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic after being scratched by a stray cat. The scratch is superficial and there is no oozing of blood. She has not had a tetanus shot in the past 10 years. How should this exposure be classified and managed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II exposure – administer tetanus vaccine and consider rabies post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Option B:

 

Class II exposure includes minor scratches or abrasions without bleeding. Tetanus vaccination should be updated if necessary, and rabies post-exposure prophylaxis may be considered, especially if the stray cat's rabies vaccination status is unknown.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Class I exposure typically includes touching or feeding animals, and licks on intact skin.

 

Option C. Class III exposure involves transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin, mucous membrane exposure, or direct contact with bats.

 

Option D. All animal scratches or bites should be assessed for potential exposure to rabies, especially if the animal's vaccination status is unknown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk categorization and recommended anti-rabies prophylaxis according to WHO guidelines (2018):

 

 

In India post-exposure prophylaxis is indicated following exposure to any animal bite except rodents and bat bite.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p500-501, 2/e p521-522

choices.text: Observe the dog for 10 days while beginning rabies post-exposure prophylaxis.
Observe the dog for 10 days before deciding on post-exposure prophylaxis.
Euthanize the dog and perform a brain biopsy to rule out rabies.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after being bitten by an unvaccinated neighbor's dog. The dog is captured and appears healthy. There is no history of rabies in the area. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Observe the dog for 10 days while beginning rabies post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Option B:

 

When bitten by an unvaccinated dog, it is appropriate to begin rabies post-exposure prophylaxis immediately due to the higher risk. The dog should also be observed for 10 days for any signs of rabies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rabies post-exposure prophylaxis is indicated but observing the dog could provide additional information regarding the rabies status.

 

Option C. Delaying post-exposure prophylaxis could be risky, especially with an unvaccinated dog.

 

Option D. Euthanizing the animal is not the first step unless it shows signs of rabies or if it is not possible to observe the dog.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate management of a patient bitten by an unvaccinated dog, emphasizing the importance of initiating rabies post-exposure prophylaxis while observing the dog for 10 days for any signs of the disease.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p500-501, 2/e p521-522, Park 24/e p296, 23/e p276-81

choices.text: Immediate wound cleansing with soap and water, followed by rabies post-exposure prophylaxis
Immediate primary wound closure with sutures under antibiotic coverage
Immediate administration of rabies immune globulin (RIG) around the wound and rabies vaccination
Immediate intravenous administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and observation for signs of rabies

questions.text: A 40-year-old male hiker presents to the emergency room after being bitten on the leg by a dog while trekking in a rural area. The dog, which appeared wild, has not been captured. The bite is deep with active bleeding. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immediate administration of rabies immune globulin (RIG) around the wound and rabies vaccination

 

Option C:

 

For class III dog bites, particularly when the dog is wild and not captured, the immediate administration of RIG and rabies vaccination is essential. RIG provides passive immunity, while the vaccination begins the process of active immunity. Immediate and thorough wound cleansing is also critical but is considered part of the initial wound management, not a treatment per se.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While immediate wound cleansing with soap and water is essential for all animal bites, it is not sufficient alone for class III exposures; post-exposure prophylaxis is also necessary.

 

Option B. Primary closure of animal bite wounds, especially those at high risk for rabies, is generally avoided to reduce the risk of infection. Wounds should be left open to heal by secondary intention unless absolutely necessary.

 

Option D. Broad-spectrum antibiotics may be used to prevent bacterial infection secondary to the dog bite, but they do not address the risk of rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of severe animal bites (class III), emphasizing the need for immediate rabies prophylaxis with RIG and vaccination, along with wound care, but avoiding primary wound closure due to infection risk.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology1/e p500-501, 2/e p521-522, PSM Park 24/e p296, 23/e p276-81

choices.text: Secondary bacterial pneumonia due to Streptococcus pneumonia
Primary viral pneumonia due to Influenza virus
Lung abscess due to Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with a high fever, cough, and worsening dyspnea. He reports that he had a flu-like illness two weeks ago, which he thought he had recovered from. His chest X-ray shows new bilateral infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary bacterial pneumonia due to Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

Option A:
 

The patient's history of a recent influenza-like illness followed by worsening respiratory symptoms and new bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray is suggestive of a secondary bacterial pneumonia, commonly due to Streptococcus pneumoniae. Influenza can predispose to secondary bacterial pneumonia, especially in patients with underlying lung disease like COPD.

 

Explanation:


Option B. Exacerbation of underlying COPD - While this is a consideration, the acute presentation with high fever and new infiltrates following influenza-like illness is more indicative of a secondary infection.
 

Option C. Primary viral pneumonia due to Influenza virus - The patient had influenza-like illness two weeks ago, and the current presentation is more consistent with a secondary bacterial complication.
 

Option D. Lung abscess due to Staphylococcus aureus - This is less likely given the bilateral nature of infiltrates and the clinical context.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The common complication of secondary bacterial pneumonia following an influenza infection, especially in patients with underlying lung conditions like COPD. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common pathogen responsible for such secondary infections. Understanding the progression from a viral illness to a bacterial complication is crucial in managing respiratory infections in patients with chronic lung diseases.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p475,481
